newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: PACCAR COMPLETES TAKEOVER OF DAF TRUCKS.
newsitem.headline: PACCAR COMPLETES TAKEOVER OF DAF TRUCKS.

text.p: U.S truck-maker Paccar Inc. has completed its friendly 933 million guilder takeover of the Netherlands' DAF Trucks NV, by acquiring 100 percent of the shares, DAF Trucks said on Friday.
The deal consolidates Paccar's position as the world's third biggest producer of heavy trucks with annual sales of $6.3 billion based on the combined 1995 figures of DAF and Paccar.
In the United States Paccar makes Peterbilt and Kenworth trucks and in Europe it has now added DAF to its Foden trucks business in Britain.
DAF Trucks chairman Cor Baan said the Paccar takeover would help further strengthen confidence in the Dutch company which was relaunched after being declared bankrupt in 1993.
"Cooperation in a broader framework under the protective umbrella of Paccar Inc. gives DAF Trucks the opportunity to develop and grow further," he said.
Paccar and DAF jointly announced the friendly takeover bid on October 7, saying it was backed by DAF's two main management organs, the executive board and the supervisory board.
The deal appears to set the seal on DAF's recovery, following the bankruptcy of the old DAF NV in February 1993.
The old DAF acquired the British Leyland commercial vehicles business in 1987 but was forced into bankruptcy six years later as a result of mounting losses and crippling debts.
The British operations were sold off and a new company, with the Dutch and Flemish governments as major shareholders, was set up to continue DAF's core heavy trucks business.
The new DAF Trucks NV, with a smaller labour force and working strictly to customer orders, gradually clawed its way back to profitability.
DAF made a net profit of 164 million guilders on sales of 2.9 billion guilders in 1995, producing over 16,600 trucks.
In the same year Paccar made a net profit of $253 million on sales of $4.6 billion and produced over 54,000 trucks.
Paccar said last month it expected DAF immediately to make a positive contribution to earnings, adding that its cost structure was among the lowest in Europe.
